column1: Will the IMF estimate for world GDP growth for 2021 be higher in its April 2021 World Economic Outlook report relative to its October 2020 report?
column6: ['Business', 'Economic Indicators']
current data and very close to deadline

The IMF update in Jan 2021 has already revised the October 2020 projection from 5.2% to 5.5% based on the active vaccination efforts and the quick turnaround by China. https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2021/01/26/2021-world-economic-outlook-update.

recent news flow + us vaccination - eu vaccination maybe on balance somewhat more positive but with assymetric vaccination in rich countries, let alone the rest of the world, risks (mutation mostly) to the downside
Time update

Uptick 75 to 85, following the trend but also convinced the numbers will suggest big growth projections based on what was stated by Jerome Powell today after the Feds meeting anticipating 6.5% growth this year
Vaccines + US stimulus. Maybe negative on Eurozone

Fabricated GDP

IMF predicted a 5.5% increase as of January 2021. Nothing suggests that this should change or that it should drop below the October 2020 prediction of 5.2%. https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2021/01/26/2021-world-economic-outlook-update#:~:text=Amid%20exceptional%20uncertainty%2C%20the%20global,and%204.2%20percent%20in%202022.
By now every major organization or bank has put the world GDP growth over 5.2% https://odishatv.in/business_economy/world-gdp-to-grow-5-6-if-vaccines-roll-out-fast-524988

As they will be putting the forecast together now, there is nothing to suggest that they should reduce their Jan forecast of 5.5%, if anything with Biden's stimulus package passed, they may even bump it higher.

Obviously, the vaccine rollout (worldwide) will make a difference to numerous segments of the markets, even if rollout is slower than hoped. Biden administration has started to pull back some tariffs and is engaging in a behind-the-scenes set of discussions with a variety of countries under the rubric of "studying" the current tariffs. It seems probable that various countries will come to near-term partial agreements with the US where there are easy wins. These tariff relaxations should provide some GDP push. Now that the Trump administration is out of office, China may decide there is a more favorable landscape to more-fully meet their agricultural purchases/promises. And, looking at just the US, rail traffic is increasing.

The current IMF World Economic Outlook is at 5.5 percent with a potent driver being the emerging markets group of countries that have been coping with COVID-19 fairly well and are not looking to be hit by a hard third wave of infections. Even if a third wave of COVID variants should hit Europe and the developed world as current case numbers indicate, it is unlikely for it to push the global average below 5.2 percent as long as esp. Asia remains relatively stable.

Yes. We are already seeing an economic growth in the United States and China. With the approval of vaccines and organizations such as COVAX working to distribute vaccines along with multinational cooperation to slow the corona virus and distribute vaccines the economy will continue to improve. The IMF estimates growth will continue and economies will continue to improve as long as countries continue to work together to stop the spread of the corona virus and help developing countries access vaccines. There is still a chance that the variants we are beginning to see will get out of hand. https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2021/01/26/2021-world-economic-outlook-update

 In my assessment, the IMF estimate is almost certainly going to be higher in its April 2021 World Economic Outlook report relative to its October 2020 report. The IMF has since released a January 2021 World Economic Outlook Update to account for policy support and vaccines to increase economic activity (IMF, 2021). Due to the support of the international community in combating COVID-19, economic relief and activity has increased and the market has adapted to redirect the course of economic growth over 2021. With the ability to obtain the COVID-19 vaccines becoming widely available soon, the impact to the economy has softened and thus allowed for a stronger recovery in the market (IMF, 2021). Policy implementations such as providing for households, providing resources for healthcare facilities, and economic policies to limit persistent damage have all aggressively combatted the damage of COVID-19 (IMF, 2021). The 15% No estimate in my assessment pertains to the impact of differing strains of the COVID-19 virus. While the vaccines have proved to be effective in most sectors, if a new strain of the virus is not combatted effectively by the virus, more research, containment strategies, and economic recovery programs could stall the hopeful outlook outlined in the January 2021 World Economic Outlook Update (IMF, 2021).

I anticipate that growth will outperform all models and that will lead to increased optimism regarding the markets. This will be especially true if MRNA vaccinations prove to be easily tweakable to combat variants. News can be a force-multiplier, good or bad. I suspect that after 2020, a year of relieving news will seep into market predictions.

The IMF estimate for world GDP growth for 2021 will be higher. Due to the covid-19 vaccine rollout, there is a more positive outlook for the world GDP. CNBC states that “the institution now excepts the global economy to grow 5.5% this year – a 0.3 percentage point increase from October’s forecasts” (Amaro, 2021).

In January 2021, the IMF put out an updated World Economic Outlook. This updated report states “After an estimated 3.5 percent contraction in 2020, the global economy is projected to grow 5.5 percent in 2021 and 4.2 percent in 2022. The estimate for 2020 is 0.9 percentage point higher than projected in the October WEO forecast. This reflects the stronger than-expected recovery on average across regions in the second half of the year. The 2021 growth forecast is revised up 0.3 percentage point, reflecting additional policy support in a few large economies and expectations of a vaccine-powered strengthening of activity later in the year, which outweigh the drag on near-term momentum due to rising infections” (IMF 2021, p. 5).
Probability: 97%

"In our latest World Economic Outlook, we are projecting global growth for 2021 to be 5.5 percent, which is 0.3 percentage points above our previous forecast. And then growth is expected to moderate to 4.2 percent in 2022. The upgrade is owing to positive effects that have come upon with the onset of vaccinations in many countries and also because of the additional fiscal policy support that has been provided in some economies like the US and Japan." Says Gita Gopinath, the Economic Counselor, and Director, Research Department, IMF.

America's labor market serves as a good litmus test for analyzing the global economy. Unemployment is particularly helpful in determining the outlook of global futures. The US labor market recovered faster than expected with a unemployment rate of 6.9% reported in OCT2020. However, the true state of employment will emerge once the heavy government aid subsides (Curr, 2020). The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) projected that all G-20 countries, other than China, would experience a recession in 2020 as a result of the pandemic. The global GDP will not return to pre-pandemic levels until Q3 2021. While the OECD projections differed from November 2019 to September 2020 given the sharp dip caused by the pandemic lockdowns, the rate of growth remain largely the same (World Economic Fund, n.d.). However, the global GDP is not expected to extend above pre-pandemic levels until 2022. The continuance of the pandemic and associated economic impacts have suppressed economic predictions going into 2021 (Ritcher, 2021). In June, 2020, the IMF reported a 1.9 percent decrease in economic growth as compared to its April, 2020 predictions. For 2021, the IMF forecasted a 5.4 percent growth in GDP, which is 6.5 percent lower than the predictions made in January 2020 prior to the pandemic (IMF, 2020). In October, 2020, the IMF projected a 5.2 percent growth in world GDP for 2021.

According to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and others, the global economy will experience growth in the near future. IMF made a statement that “amid exceptional uncertainty, the global economy is projected to grow 5.5 percent in 2021 and 4.2 percent in 2022” (World Economic Outlook Update). In comparison to the previous estimate, the 2021 prediction has been raised by 0.3 percentage point. Indicating that the expectations for a vaccine-driven boost in development later this year, as well as additional policy support in a few advanced economies. So with this knowledge there is a 95% chance for the GDP growth to be higher in April 2021.

The IMF has already posted an updated report this year, stating the following: “Amid exceptional uncertainty, the global economy is projected to grow 5.5 percent in 2021 [...] The 2021 forecast is revised up 0.3 percentage point relative to the previous forecast, reflecting expectations of a vaccine-powered strengthening of activity later in the year and additional policy support in a few large economies” (IMF, 2021). In addition, just last week China set an increased goal for their GDP growth in 2021 (China rebounds with economic growth target above 6%, 2021). Therefore, leaving the (extremely low) possibility of an impactful, unforeseen world event, there is almost a 100% chance that the IMF estimate for world GDP growth for 2021 will be higher in its April 2021 World Economic Outlook report relative to its October 2020 report, as it already personally reported that the outlook has been revised to a higher projection.

According to most recent world economic outlook report, world GDP growth is suspected to rise. While not entirely certain, it is safe to predict that this will be the case and the the estimate in the April 2021 report will be higher than the October 2020 report.

Since the October 2020 issue of the World Economic Outlook, the IMF released a January 2021 World Outlook update which projects the global economy to grow 5.5% this year. The report states that the growth is a recovery from 2020’s severe collapse, revised by 0.3% from the previous projection of 5.152%. This 0.3% increase reflects “expectations of a vaccine-powered strengthening of activity”. The recovery will vary across countries and regions, dependent on access to medical interventions, effective policy support, and infection spillovers from other countries. Despite the toll of the pandemic on the economy and people, economic activity is adapting. There are, however, risks to this outlook. If progress is slower-than-anticipated and there is a struggle to contain the virus and vaccinate people, this could weaken confidence and lead to withdrawn policy support. Growth is going to depend on vaccine rollout and the incidence of COVID-19 infections. Though, it is expected that therapies will gradually become more widely accessible during 2021-2022. By the end of 2022, local transmission of the virus will be brought down to lower levels everywhere.

According to a World Economic Outlook (WEO) Update published by the IMF in January 2021, the IMF notes that “policy support and vaccines expected to lift activity,” revising its previous 2021 forecast of estimated world GDP growth from October 2020 from 5.152% to 5.5.%. It does note that its prediction is clouded in uncertainty, complicated by hopes from vaccine approvals and concerns from new virus variants, but that its increase of 0.3. percentage points reflects “expectations of a vaccine-powered strengthening of activity later in the year and additional policy support in a few large economies.” I believe that the predictions that IMF will make in its April 2021 WEO report will depend on the success of vaccine rollouts, country policies aimed at economic recovery, and multilateral cooperation to aid low-income developing countries in recovery over the next month. These things are hard to forecast, but with new vaccines being administered and distributed each day, countries aimed at reigniting their economies, and rising international cooperation to distribute vaccines to low-income countries, I expect the IMF estimate for world GDP growth for 2021 be higher in its April 2021 World Economic Outlook report relative to its October 2020 report. Additionally, the WHO There are factors that could cause the estimate to decrease, such as international conflicts, rapid spread of COVID variants, or evidence of vaccine failure, which is why I am leaving a 2% possibility of a decrease, but I do not foresee any major changes occurring within the next month before the April 2021 report is released.

The IMF predicted a 5.5% growth for 2021 and 4.2% for 2022, this is due to the rollout of COVID vaccinations and some of the lessening of the grip of the pandemic. This will more than likely instill faith in their next estimate compared to the one in October.

The IMF released an update in January of 2021 projecting a .3% growth relative to its October 2020 report (https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2021/01/26/2021-world-economic-outlook-update). With vaccinations continuing well and with increasing production, the world will more quickly return to prepandemic levels of economic output, particularly in the U.S. which makes up a large percentage of the world’s GDP. As well as China, showing a projected 8.3 percentage growth and India showing a 11.5 percentage growth in 2021. This projected percentage increases show strong confidence that the April 2021 world GDP growth in the Work Economic Outlook will be much higher than the October 2020 report.

Vaccination for Covid-19 is beginning to take hold of the virus and reduce the new cases reported, along with pandemic control efforts. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has in fact already published an update in January 2021 which increased its estimate for world gross domestic production (GDP) growth from 5.152% to 5.5%, citing development of vaccines against coronavirus and effective policy support to recovery efforts. A few pandemic related concerns raised in the update include further spread of coronavirus and logistical challenges to vaccine distribution. According to the John Hopkins global tracker, global daily cases have slightly decreased since the new estimate, returning to levels like those seen in October 2020. Also, Google’s calculation of available data shows that ten times as many people are fully vaccinated as there were on 26 January 2021 and almost three times as many people have received at least one dose of the vaccine. Furthermore, the recent U.S. Food and Drug Administration emergency use authorization of the Johnson and Johnson vaccine should provide additional optimism for the April estimate. One other risk previously identified was the impact of a “no-deal Brexit”, which the latest report dismisses due to the December agreement between the United Kingdom and the European Union. Based on these factors, I predict with almost certainty that the IMF will maintain an estimate higher than 5.152% for global GDP growth in the April report. I have assigned a 97% chance for this to occur, with only a 3% chance based on the possibility of issues in the efficacy of some vaccines or the rapidly increased spread of the virus due to early lifting of pandemic restrictions.

In the last decade, actual annual global GDP was <5%. Why it will be <5%? According to a World Bank blog, it is estimated that 80% of economies will be in contraction mode in 2021. There have been a dozen recessions in the last 80 years. As per the graph, in only one instance (2010), the bounce was > 5% immediately after a recession. Hence, with these facts, I believe the forecast will be <5%. I will correct with more facts.
Rising interest rates during a global recession are generally a sign of a strengthening global economy.[1]
Lowering based on rising interest rates.

I am improving my forecast from 65% to 75% confidence that the IMF estimate for global GDP growth for 2021 will be higher in April 2021 than what was forecast in Oct 2020 report (5.152%) due to two recent reports: one from Goldman Sachs in which it raised its US GDP forecast by 0.5% to 6.4%, and one from Morgan Stanley which raised its global GDP forecast from 5.9% to 6.4%. The Morgan Stanley report that we are now entering the self-sustaining phase of the V-shaped recovery initially projected in 2020. This assessment directly conflicts with the initial worries this past fall that the pandemic will have a bigger impact on private-sector risk appetite and, hence, global growth; however, experts say that consumers have driven the recovery. To continue progress in economic recovery, the reports state that 3 key factors will characterize the next stage: synchronized global growth, an emerging-market rebound, and the return of inflation. So I will be looking for these indicators in news/reporting to determine whether my confidence will increase or decrease in the coming weeks.

Looks like consensus by analyst is 5.4% for 2021 [1] Goldman Sachs raises US GDP forecast for 2021[2]

I forecasted with 65% confidence that yes, the IMF estimate for world GDP growth for 2021 will be higher in its April 2021 report than the 5.152% it estimated in its October 2020 report. I am cautiously optimistic that the IMF's estimate will increase in its next report since October because we have gained a clearer picture of COVID-19 spread and the roll-out of vaccines was ahead of expectation. There are many advanced economic nations that have had positive monetary policy responses. I also think there will be a stronger global, internationalized response to combatting the virus in 2021 than there was in 2020. However, I am tempering my positivity because it is unknown just how much lasting damage the pandemic has inflicted on the global economy, from shutting down businesses, unemployment, government intervention to bail out. It is also unknown how rapid the virus recovery can take place in emerging and developing economies compared to advanced economies.

The IMF growth forecasts, both from October for the next year and from April for the current year, appear to be statistically biased only in that they, in common with other forecasts, underestimate the likelihood of a recession (http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.587.9776&rep=rep1&type=pdf). Having just had a recession, a new one's unlikely in the next three months (https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0232615 implies <1% chance), so I'll base probability estimates on other forecasts released since October 2020. The IMF's October 2020 forecast of 5.152% is slightly lower than the average of more recent forecasts, with the OECD's December forecast being 4.2% (https://www.oecd.org/economic-outlook/), Fitch's 5.3% (https://www.fitchratings.com/research/sovereigns/world-gdp-recovery-to-strengthen-from-mid-2021-on-vaccine-rollout-07-12-2020), Morgan Stanley's 6.4% (https://www.morganstanley.com/ideas/global-economic-outlook-2021), Citi's 5.0% (https://www.citi.co.in/portal/pdf/annual-outlook.pdf), and Consensus Economics' November forecast 5.9% (calculated from a PWC average, https://www.pwc.com/gx/en/research-insights/economy/global-economy-watch/projections.html). Those forecasts are consistent with their prior versions (2.8 - 5.2% by the OECD in June, http://www.oecd.org/economic-outlook/june-2020/, 5.2% by Fitch in September, same link as prev.), so neither vaccines' better-than-expected performance nor worse-than-expected late-Autumn case numbers seem to have dominated other effects on growth forecasts, but indicators like the OECD's CLI provide indications that might make those more recent forecasts closer to the IMF April forecast (https://www.econstor.eu/handle/10419/180842).
Vaccine development much further ahead of schedule than predicted in their October report - impacting on GDP recoveries from Covid-19 pandemic.

A majority of the forecasts that have come out from reputable institutions since October that I could find are higher than the IMF's. Not all, but most. So my base rate was a bit better than 50/50 for an upward revision.

Plus I think we are supposed to expect a much worse Q1 than would have been anticipated in September. Also 5.15% seems high even following a bad year. However, the number doesn't include the vaccines approval that happened in November but also it doesn't include the worsening situation in the economy that we are seeing at the moment and that i think it will continue until the rolled out of the vaccines are large enough, probably later than expected, late second half. So net net, the situation in April should be worse. Summary: in last October there were high expectations for 2021 GDP growth, the vaccines approval won't have a meaningful effect in 2021´s GDP above what it was already expected, however the REAL situation is worse.

My guess is that the IMF probably wasn't anticipating a quick vaccine rollout. I think vaccine rollout may be be above most expectations in the first quarter of next year, leading to a potential for a quicker return to normal than the IMF would have anticipated in October of 2020 and maybe more economic activity in Q1 of next year.

In general the IWF has a tendency to overestimate the growth for the next year in it's April forecast. But during crises it seems to be the opposite which is the first reason I'm leaning slightly to more to yes. Also, the Covid19 Pandemic has been less severe than in October predicted which leads to the same conclusion. [ https://covid19.healthdata.org/global?view=total-deaths&tab=trend ] [https://web.archive.org/web/20201002070629if_/https://covid19.healthdata.org/global?view=total-deaths&tab=trend ]

It looks like the test thresholds are going to change as the the vaccine is rolled out. The WHO just released a paper acknowledging that PCR tests with high cycle thresholds can have false positives. This opens the door for all jurisdictions to ensure that their testing thresholds are flow the levels that can create false positives. This information has been known for a long time. The New York times reported on it in the summer. Dr Fachi acknowledged it several months ago. Previously I believe it was believed by the authorities that having false positives was beneficial because it was better to err on the side of caution and it helped to justify stronger lockdowns. Now that the vaccine is being distributed changing the test threshold amounts will help it look like the vaccine is working, restoring public confidence. Florida has recently required its testing centers to report what their cycle thresholds are I believe that this will be a trend among all jurisdictions, which will lead to many fewer positive test results.

Base rate: ever since the GFC of 2008-2009 the IMF has been predicting too much growth 1-2 years out. I currently identify at least one opposite force: The more "negative" economic impact (GDP reduction) economists have been putting in 2020, the higher the subsequent 2021 growth has been set. Arguably, the short term economic news about Corona has been deteriorating since the October report. More bad news is expected as gov measures are playing a huge role in western world in avoiding mass bankruptcies and unemployment. Thats a negative for 2020 However, in April, vaccination efforts should be well under way in most parts of the (western) world. I would say vaccination-related news has improved somewhat since october Thats a positive for 2021

Whilst there is vaccine and distribution has begun, governments are likely to employ greater restrictions during the first quarter of the year - limiting overall growth for the year. Some countries will be better off than forecast (China) as seen from its stronger recovery.

The October forecast, whilst doubtless assuming a vaccine would be available in the early part of 2021, may not have anticipated approval of any vaccines and the start of vaccination programs quite as quickly as has happened. Given economic recovery rates have generally been quicker than initially anticipated throughout the crisis, it seems likely by April things will be looking on the up. One caveat is how serious the post-Christmas period COVID uptick becomes - hence a 3-1 chance.
Too much uncertainty as of now.

The Oct 2020 forecast improved over the Jun 2020 forecast, indicating the assumption that the global economy in moving forward. WIth the news of a vaccine coming into production late 4Q 2020 and increasing volume in 1Q 2021, it should give hope to improved global growth. This should be especially true in developed countries which should get access to the vaccine more easily allowing for a quicker rebound. There are still questions about when enough vaccines will be available to make a major economic impact and how countries will handle getting their economies on track. However, given the OCT 2020 report indicated a 4% contaction, it is highly likely the global economy should make enough of a rebound by April 2021 to improve over Oct 2020.

An over/under on the IMF forecasting algorithm, this is a loser. Note to self: you should of turned around and walked away. The IMF forecast is a baseline and then it has upside and downside scenarios. In october the forecasters (I think) would not have included first quarter lockdowns as stringent as in 1 Q 2020. So potential on the downside revision just based on what is occurr in December. There is minimum historical data for a global synchronized recession for a forecaster to prepare a reliable model to make a future prediction about the rebound strength. Basically theyare relying on past precedent of no recession last greater than 12 months and the recovery is robust in the first quarter of the recovery and continues on for three quarters following. The 2009 recession demonstrated that recessions can expand and u-bottom or flatline. There are other unknowns like the impact of lifting of payment moratoriums on consumers (rent and education bills), rebuilding of savings rates, informal economy activity access to money and materials, moving foreign workers back to the countries employing them, and recovery in oil comsumption. To conclude all these unknowns makes me lean to the under.

The biggest problems with the world economy do not include the virus. Authoritarianism is on the rise in the developed world. I don't see economies springing back to recover lost ground now that we have a vaccine. The effects of the debt and business closings from the government response to the virus have yet to fully hit us.
Although projections are now trending -0.2 percentage points below the IMF June projection.Growth is still projected to rebound in 2021 to 5.2 percent,
Reflation and snap back will revive growth forecasts.

%5.15 is too pessimistic given the recent news. Global growth averages at about %2.5 per year and there is likely to be a little over %4 contraction in GDP in 2020, making for an especially low base rate. That means world GDP is about %6.5 below trend, and it only needs to gain less than half of the distance back to the trend line in order to do better than the IMF forecast. Recovery in monthly data measuring economic activity is strong; such as PMI, other measures of manufacturing output and unemployment. The shock appears to not be very persistent. The vaccine news, which was not available as of October 2020, should also improve the situation.
